titleStmt.title: The dragon of Wantley: A burlesque opera. The musick by Mr. John Frederick Lampe, and performed at the Theatre-Royal in Covent-Garden. Moderniz'd from the old ballad after the Italian manner, by Sig. Carini.
titleStmt.author: Carey, Henry, 1687?-1743.

fileDesc.extent: 23 600dpi bitonal TIFF page images and SGML/XML encoded text

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The dragon of Wantley: A burlesque opera. The musick by Mr. John Frederick Lampe, and performed at the Theatre-Royal in Covent-Garden. Moderniz'd from the old ballad after the Italian manner, by Sig. Carini.
titleStmt.author: Carey, Henry, 1687?-1743.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original from the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE DRAGON OF WANTLEY. A BURLESQUE OPERA. The MUSICK By Mr. JOHN FREDERICK LAMPE, And Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Govent-Garden. Moderniz'd from the OLD BALLAD after the Italian Manner, by Sig. CARINI.
LONDON: Printed for J. SHUCKBURGH, at the Sun near the Inner-Temple-Gate in Fleet-ſtreet, 1737. (Price Six-pence.)

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
div.p: SCENE that Part of Yorkſhire near Rotheram.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: FLY, Neighbours, fly,
The Dragon's nigh,
Save your Lives and fly;
Away, away,
For if you ſtay,
Sure as a Gun you die. Fly, &c.

sp.speaker: Gub.
sp.l: What wretched Havock does this Dragon make!
He ſticks at nothing for his Belly's Sake:
Feeding but makes his Appetite the ſtronger,
He'll eat us all, if he 'bides here much longer!

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: Houſes and Churches,
To Him are Geeſe and Turkies.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: O Father! Father! as our noble 'Squire
Was ſate at Breakfaſt by his Parlour Fire,
With Wife and Children, all in pleaſant Tattle,
The Table ſhook, the Cups began to rattle;
A diſmal Noiſe was heard within the Hall,
Away they flew, the Dragon ſcar'd them all:
He drank up all their Coffee at a Sup,
And next devour'd their Toaſt and Butter up.

lg.l: But to hear the Children mutter,
When they'd loſt their Toaſt and Butter,
And to ſee my Lady moan,
Oh! 'twould melt a Heart of Stone.
There the Maids and Miſtreſs jangling,
Oh! 'twould make one's Heart to ake. But to hear, &c.

sp.speaker: Gub
sp.l: This Dragon very modiſh, ſure, and nice is:
What ſhall we do in this diaſt'rous Criſis?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: A Thought, to quell him, comes into my Head;
No way more proper than to kill him dead.

sp.speaker: Gub.
sp.l: O Miracle of Wiſdom! rare Suggeſtion!
But how, or who to do it, that's the Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Not far from hence there lives a valiant Knight,
A Man of Proweſs great, and mickle Might:
He has done Deeds St. George himſelf might brag on;

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: This very Man is he ſhall kill the Dragon.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: He's a Man ev'ry Inch, I aſſure you,
There's none can from Danger ſecure you,
Like brave gallant Moore of Moore-Hall.
No Giant or Knight e'er quell'd him,
He fills all their Hearts with Alarms;
No Virgin yet ever beheld him,
But wiſh'd herſelf claſp'd in his Arms.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: Let's go to his Dwelling,
With Yelping and Yelling;
We'll move him to Pity,
And tell him, and tell him a ſorrowful Ditty.

div.head: SCENE, Moore-Hall.
Symphony.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Come, Friends, let's circulate the cheerful Glaſs;
Let each true Toper toaſt his favourite Laſs.
Sound all your Inſtruments of Joy, and play:
Let's drink and ſing, and paſs the Time away.

l.hi: All were Lovers of the Bottle;
Love and Drinking are no Treaſon.

div.stage: Enter GUBBINS, MAUXALINDA, MARGERY, and others.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: Moore of Moore-Hall!

l.hi: And leave us the Devil a Rag on.

sp.l: [O ſave, &c.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Pink of Proweſs, and good Breeding,
Let a Virgin's Tears inſpire thee;
Let a Maiden's Bluſhes fire thee.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Her Looks ſhoot thro' my Soul, her Eyes ſtrike Fire;
I'm all a Conflagration of Deſire.
Fair Maid, I grant whatever you can ask,
The Deed is done, when once you name the Task.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: The Dragon, Sir, the Dragon!

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Say no more,
You ſoon ſhall ſee him weltring in his Gore.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Moſt mighty Moore! do but this Dragon kill,
All that we have is wholly at your Will.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: The only Bounty I require, is this,
That thou may'ſt fire me with an ardent Kiſs;
That thy ſoft Hands may 'noint me over Night,
And dreſs me in the Morning e'er I fight.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: A forward Lady! ſhe grows fond apace,
But I ſhall catch her in a proper Place.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Leave her with me; conclude the Dragon dead:
If I don't maul the Dog, I'll loſe my Head.

div.stage: [All go off but Moore and Margery.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Let my Deareſt be near me;

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'll ever be near thee.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: To warm me, to cheer me;

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: To warm thee, to cheer thee.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: To fire me, inſpire me;

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: To fire thee, inſpire thee

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: With Kiſſes and Ale.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Your Fears I'll aboliſh;

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: This Dragon demoliſh.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I'll work him;

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Ay, work him.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I'll jerk him;

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: [Let my, &c.

div.stage: MOORE leads off MARGERY; MAUXALINDA enters, and pulls him back by the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: O Villain! Monſter! Devil! Baſely baſe!
How can you dare to look me in the Face?
Did you not ſwear laſt Chriſtmas we ſhould marry?
Oh, 'tis enough to make a Maid miſcarry!
Witneſs this Piece of Six-pence, certain Token
Of my true Heart, and your falſe Promiſe broken.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: The Devil's in the Woman! What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: Now you inſult me; Time was, you cou'd flatter.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Upon my Soul, I don't know what you mean!

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: Don't you know Margery of Roth'ram-Green?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Not I, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: That's a Lie.
What do you think I've neither Ear nor Eye.
Villain! I will believe my Eyes and Ears!
She whom you kiſs'd, and call'd ten thouſand Dears.
Let my Deareſt be near me, &c.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: By Jove! I'm blown. Zounds! how came this about?
However, I'm reſolv'd to ſtand it out.

sp.speaker: To Maux.
sp.l: I only out of Policy was civil;
But, 'faith, I hate her as I hate the Devil.
You're all I value, witneſs this cloſe Hug,
I'm yours, and only yours.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: Ah Coaxing Pug!

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My pretty Mauxy, prithee don't be jealous.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: Dear me! you Men are ſuch bewitching Fellows;
You ſteal into our Hearts by ſly Degrees,
Then make poor Girls believe juſt what you pleaſe.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: By the Beer, as brown as Berry;
By the Cyder and the Perry,
Which ſo oft has made us merry,

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: But do you really love me?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: By this Kiſs,
By Raptures paſt, and Hopes of future Bliſs.

lg.head: DUETTO.
lg.l: We will out-cooe the Turtle Dove.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: MARGERY ſola.
sp.l: SURE my Stays will burſt with ſobbing,
And my Heart quite crack with throbbing.
My poor Eyes are red as Ferrets,
And I ha'n't a Grain of Spirits.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Madge! my Honey-ſuckle, in the Dumps!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Put your Hand here, and feel my Heart how't thumps.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Good lack a day! how great a Palpitation!
Tell me, my Dear! the Cauſe of this Vexation.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: An ugly Dream has put me in a Fright;
I dreamt the Dragon ſlew my gentle Knight:
If ſuch a thing ſhould happen unto thee,
O miſerable, miſerable, Margery!

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Don't fright thy ſelf with Dreams, my Girl, ne'er fear him,
I'll work his Buff, if ever I come near him.
I've ſuch a Suit of ſpiked Armour bought,
Bears, Lions, Dragons, it will ſet at nought:
In which, when I'm equip'd, my Madge ſhall ſee,
I'll ſcare the Dragon, not the Dragon me.
But Time grows ſhort, I muſt a while away.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Make haſte, my Dear!

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Duck! I will not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: So Madam! have I found you out at laſt?
You now ſhall pay full dear for all that's paſt.
Were you as fine as e'er wore Silk or Sattin,
I'd beat your Harlot's Brains out with my Pattin,
Before you ſhall delude a Man of mine.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Who in the Name of Wonder made him thine?

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: D'ye laugh, you Minx! I'll make you change your Note,
Or drive your grinning Grinders down your Throat.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Lauk, what a monſtrous Tail our Cat has got!

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: Nay, if you brave me, then you go to pot.
Come, Bodkin, come! take Mauxalinda's Part,
And ſtab her hated Rival to the Heart.

div.stage: Enter MOORE, takes away the Bodkin.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Why, what the Devil is the Woman doing!

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: To put an End to all your Worſhip's Wooing.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: 'Tis well I came, before the Whim went further;
Had I ſtay'd longer, here had ſure been Murder.
This curſed Jade has thrown the Girl in Fits.
How do'ſt, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Frighted out of my Wits.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: But fear her not, for by her own Confeſſion,
I'll bind her over to the Quarter-Seſſion.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: O give me not up to the Law,
I'd much rather beg upon Crutches;
You never get out of his Clutches.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Come, come, forgive her.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Here my Anger ends.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: And ſo does mine.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Why then let's buſs and Friends.

sp.speaker: Maux.
sp.l: Oh how eaſy is a Woman,
How deluding are you Men!
Oh how rare, to find a true Man,
Not ſo oft as one in ten.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Oh how charming is a Woman,
Form'd to captivate us Men;
Yet ſo eager to ſubdue Man,
That for one ſhe covets ten.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Let's reward them as they treat us,
Women prove ſincere as Men;
But if they deceive and cheat us,
Let us e'en cheat them again.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Let's reward them as they treat us, &c.

sp.speaker: Gub.
sp.l: Now, now, or never ſave us, valiant Moore!
The Dragon's coming, don't you hear him roar?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Why let him roar his Heart out, 'tis no matter:
Stand clear, my Friends, this is no Time to chatter.

sp.speaker: Gub.
sp.l: Here take your Spear.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: —I ſcorn Sword, Spear, or Dart;
I'm arm'd compleatly in a valiant Heart.
But firſt I'll drink, to make me ſtrong and mighty,
Six Quarts of Ale, and one of Aqua Vitae.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: Fill, fill, fill a mighty Flagon,
Kill, kill, kill this monſtrous Dragon.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: A rural Proſpect near the Dragon's Den.
Enter MOORE in Armour, and MARGERY.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: ONe Buſs, dear Margery, and then away.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I cannot go, my Love!

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: You muſt not ſtay.
Get up, ſweet Wench, get up in yonder Tree,
And there ſecurely you may hear and ſee.
Come, Mr. Dragon, or by Jove I'll fetch you;
I'll trim your Raſcals Jacket, if I catch you.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Dragon! Dragon! thus I dare thee:
Soon to Atoms thus I'll tear thee;
But regarding where my Dear is,
Then, alas! I feel what Fear is,

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: It is not Strength that always wins;
Good Wit does Strength excel.
Confound the Raſcal, how he grins,—
I'll creep into this Well.
sp.stage: [Enter Dragon, and goes to the Well, as to drink.

sp.speaker: Dragon.
sp.l: What naſty Dog has got into the Well,
Diſturbs my Drink, and makes the Water ſmell.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: I wiſh I'd known your Tricks before.

div.stage: [Moore gets out of the Well, and encounters the Dragon.

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.l: Oh! oh! oh!
The Devil take your Toe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Oh, my Conqu'ror! how d'ye do?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Oh, my Charmer! how are you?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Very well, thank you;

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I'm ſo too.
Your Eyes were livid, and your Cheeks were pale;
But now you look as brisk as bottled Ale.
Give me a Buſs.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Ah, twenty if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: With all my heart, and twenty after theſe.

lg.head: DUETT.
lg.l: My ſweet Honey ſuckle, my Joy and Delight,
I'll kiſs thee all Day, and I'll hug thee all Night.
My Deareſt is made of ſuch excellent Stuff,
I think I ſhall never have Kiſſing enough.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Now nimbly dance, ye Nymphs and Swains be gay,
The Dragon's dead, and you may ſafely play.

sp.speaker: Gub.
sp.l: Moſt mighty Moore, what Wonders haſt thou done,
Deſtroy'd the Dragon, and my Margery won,
The Loves of this brave Knight, and my fair Daughter,
In Roratorios ſhall be ſung hereafter.
Begin your Songs of Joy; begin, begin,
And rend the Welkin with harmonious Din.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: To gallant Morio,
Of Moore-Hall.
To Margereenia
Of Roth'ram-Greenia,
